item.title: Working with Git
item.description:
Sourcetree

There was some complex git stuff that I had to do at work and Sourcetree helped show what was going on. It’s one of those intimidating apps that does it all, but it is hepful for seeing what is happening and I like the staging options that include nesting, which I find more intuitive than RStudio’s output.

Amend Previous Commit in Sourcetree

I use this often in RStudio, but was not sure where it lived in Sourcetree. It’s essentially the “no wait, but also” button, adding in a little more to the recent commit. In RStudio, it is a prominent checkbox, but in Sourcetree, it is under “Commit Options…” in the commit dialogue.

Image Credit

Conflict by Zach Bogart from the Noun Project

item.title: Some VSCode Data Things
item.description:
Rainbow CSV

“Looking” at data can take many forms, but opening a CSV in Excel feels a little like poor form. I found Rainbow CSV for VSCode helpful for seeing the columns in a CSV. Totally an example of seeing this in the wild and going “I want that.”

Format Document

Working with a lot of JSON, there are a lot of cases where the data is not pretty, instead wrapped onto one line. Format document is quite useful and I wish there was an analog in RStudio.

item.title: RTFM Readme
item.description:
I end up making the same searches over and over. I always feel like I’m looking up the same things. So when I think of it, I’m going to try to make a blog post of it, even if it is a super minor detail. That way I can make my own little textbook of helpful tips/tricks that only gets better.

These posts are little notes to myself in the future with things I do a lot in different programs.

Image Credit

dazed and confused by Zach Bogart from the Noun Project

item.title: Hello, Quarto Site
item.description:
I’m digging Quarto. It was pretty easy to make this into a website, plus it makes adding in plots really seamless.

Challenges

Pretty painlessly, was able to revamp my website using Quarto. Some challenges encountered:

  • The navbars and sidebars are independent. I’m not using them to their full potential at the moment.
  • I can’t seem to get the blog title banner to show up on smaller screens. Even had some troubles seeing it when forking the quarto-web repo and looking at their blog. Will have to look into this.

Overall, looking forward to using Quarto more often.

Always learning,

Zach

Note

2022-04-24: I ended up getting the title and subtitle to appear in blog posts on smaller screens by copying the quarto-web repo more closely. It still feels finicky, though, like it could break if the text banner color is altered. Ongoing and will have to keep in mind when fiddling with things.

Image Credit

Coder by Zach Bogart from the Noun Project
